Notes of Game Theory

Lecture 1: Introduction

A game is a formal representation of a situation in which a number of individuals interact with strategic interdependence.

  • Key concepts: Players, Rules, Outcomes, Payoffs

Preliminaries: Convexity

  • (Convex Set) if ∀x1,x2∈χ and any θ∈[0,1], we have: θx1+(1−θ)x2∈χ

  • (Convex Combination) A convex combination of points x1,x2,⋯,xk can be expressed as y=∑i=1kθixi with ∑iθi=1 and θi≥0,i=1,2,⋯,k.

  • (Convec Hull)

  • Intersection and Affine Mapping preserves the convexity of Sets.

  • (Convex function) A function f:R→R is convex if

    • domf is convex;
    • ∀x,y∈domf,∀θ∈[0,1], we have: f(θx+(1−θ)y)≤θf(x)+(1−θ)f(y)
    • If equality doesn't hold for all θ∈(0,1), then the function is called strictly convex.

  • (Sublevel Set) The α-sublevel set of a function f:Rn→R is defined as:Cα={x∈domf:f(x)≤α}.

  • (Quasi-convex functions) A function f:Rn→R is called quasi-convex (or uni-modal) if its domain and all sublevel sets Cα={x∈domf:f(x)≤α},∀α∈R are convex.

    • A function f is quasi-linear iff both f and −f are quasi-convex.

Cournot Competition

Two companies, product level q1,q2, market command (price) 1−q1−q2. Response: q1∗=1−q22,q2∗=1−q12

 

Lecture 2: Utility and Rationality

Simple case: Decision under Certainty

Preferences are relationships defined on two choices x,y∈X for a specific agent;

  • x⪰y means the agent prefers x to y. x≻y, x∼y
  • All preferences relations between two elements constitutes a preference relation on X

For simplicity, we can use Utilities to describe Preferences, as if the following axioms holds:

  • Completeness: ∀x,y∈X, we have either x⪰y or y⪰x, or both.
  • Transitivity: If x⪰y,y⪰z, then x⪰z. (Plausible?)

With these two axioms, we can define the agent's best choice rule on X as:

C(X;⪰)={x∈X:x⪰y,∀y∈X}

Proposition(Exsitence):

  • For every finite non-empty set B, we have C(B;⪰)≠∅
  • If x,y∈A∩B, and x∈C(A;⪰),y∈C(B;⪰), then we have x∈C(B;⪰),y∈C(A;⪰).
  • If X is infinite, then C(X;⪰) may be empty.

Utility

Def. A utility function μ:X→R is consistent with a preference relation ⪰ on X if ∀x,y∈X, we have x⪰y if and only if μ(x)≥μ(y).

Thm. If X is finite, and the preference relation ⪰ on X is complete and transitive, then there exists a utility function μ that is consistent with it.

Remark: Similar results can be extended to infinite countable X or infinite continuous X. Proof: Induction

Rationality

Def. An agent is rational if the agent always maximizes his utility.

 

Choice under Uncertainty: Lottery Model

Define χ as the set of possible outcomes, prizes or consequences.

  • (Lottery) A simple lottery over χ is a vector p=(p1,p2,⋯,pn) with pi≥0 for all i and ∑ipi=1, where pi is the probability that outcome xi occurs.
  • Given a space of outcome χ, denote the relevant set of lotteries over χ as P=Δ(χ)={(p1,p2,⋯,pn):pi≥0,∑ipi=1}.
  • (Compound lottery) Given two lotteries p and p′, any convex combination of them: αp+(1−α)p′ with α∈[0,1] is also a lottery.

Preference over lotteries:

  • Utility U assigns utility numbers u1,⋯,un to the n outcomes x1,x2,⋯,xn∈χ, but gives a utility U(p)=U(p;u1,u2,⋯,un) on p∈P. Then it satisifes:

    p⪰q⇔U(p)=∑x∈χp(x)u(x)≥U(q)=∑x∈χq(x)u(x)

  • Def. A utility function U:P→R is called an Expected Utility Function (or equivalently, a von Neumann-Morgenstern (VNM) expected utility function) if there is an assignment of numbers (u1,⋯,un) to the n outcomes (x1,⋯,xn) such that for every simple lottery p∈P, U(p)=u1p1+⋯+unpn.

Preferences Aioms:

  • (Independence) ∀p,p′,p″∈P and α∈[0,1], we have:

    p⪰p′⇔αp+(1−α)p″⪰αp′+(1−α)p″

  • (Continuity) if ∀p,p′,p″∈P with p⪰p′⪰p″, there exists some α∈[0,1] s.t.

    αp+(1−α)p″∼p′

Expected Utility Theorem. A preference relation ⪰ on lottery space P admits an expected utility representation if and only if it satisfies axioms of completeness, transitivity, continuity and independence.

That is, for a complete, transitive, continuous and independent preference ⪰​ on Δ(χ)​, we can assign a number u1,...un​ to each outcome x1,...,xn​ in such a manner that for any two lotteries p​ and p′​ , we have:

p⪰p′⇔∑i=1nuipi≥∑i=1nuipi′
  • Suppose that U:P→R is a VNM expected utility function for the preference relation ⪰ on P. Then V:P→R is another VNM utility function for ⪰ if and only if there are scalar a and scalar b>0 such that V(p)=a+bU(p) for all p∈P.

 

Risk Aversion

Define δx to be a degenerate lottery that gives x for certain, and E(p) be the expected value (amount of money) of a lottery p. We say that a decision maker is

  • risk-averse if for every lottery p, δE(p)⪰p.
  • risk-neutral if for every lottery p, δE(p)∼p.
  • risk-loving if for every lottery p, δE(p)⪯p.

Thm. Risk-averse ⇔ u is concave.

 

Lecture 3-4 : Strategic Form Game

Strategic Form Game

Def. (Strategic Form Game/Normal Form Game) A triplet G={I,(Si)i∈I,(ui)i∈I} s.t.

  • I is a finite set of players

  • The pure-strategy space Si is the set of available actions for player i

  • Pay-off functions: (ui)i∈I:S1×S2×⋯×SI→R.

    • ui(s) is player i's VNM utility function for each strategy profile s=(s1,s2,⋯,sI).

  • Simultaneous-move, One-shot

  • In addition, denote −i as all players except i, that is, player i's opponent.

  • Common knowledge: Every agents kows all other agent's actions, utilities, and that everyone is rational. And (everyone knows)k everyone knows it.

Dominant Strategy

Def. (Dominance) A strategy si∈Si is dominant for player i if ui(si,s−i)≥ui(si′,s−i),∀si′∈S,∀s−i∈S−i. Def. (Dominant Strategy Equilibrium) Def.* (Strictly/Weakly dominated strategy) A strategy si∈Si is strictly dominated (by a pure strategy) if there exists some other si′∈Si s.t. ui(si′,s−i)>ui(si,s−i),∀s−i∈S−i.

Iterated Elimination of Strictly Dominated Strategy

Nash Equilibrium

Def. A strategy profile s∗ is a (pure strategy) Nash equilibrium if for all players i, we have

ui(si∗,s−i∗)≥ui(si′,s−i∗),∀Si′∈Si

No player can gain by changing strategy while other players remain unchanged. （局部极值点）

Def. (Best response) Given a belief of others’ strategy profile s−i , define best response as:

Bi(s−i)={s′:arg⁡maxs′∈Siui(s′,s−i)}

Mixed Strategy

Def. For player i, a mixed strategy σi is a probabilistic distribution over pure strategies si.

  • Based on VNM utility, player i’s expected payoff ui is ui(σi)=∫Sui(s)dσ(s)
  • We define the support of a mixed strategy σi as: support(σ)={si∈Si:σi(si)>0}

Def. (Mixed Strategy Nash Equilibruim) A mixed strategy profile σ∗ is a (mixed strategy) Nash equilibrium if for every player i​,

ui(σi∗,σ−i∗)≥ui(σi′,σ−i∗),∀σi′∈Σi
  • Prop. A mixed strategy profile σ∗ is a Nash equilibrium iff for each player i∈I, every pure strategy in the support of σi∗ is a best response to σ−i∗.
  • Prop. If σ∗ is a Nash equilibrium, every pure strategy in the support of σi∗ yields the same payoff.

Iterative Elimination of Strictly Dominated Strategies with Mixed Strategy (ISD or IESDS)

Def. A pure strategy si is strictly dominated if there exists a mixed strategy σi′∈Σi such that ui(σi′,s−i)>ui(si,s−i) for all s−i∈S−i . It is equivalent to check ui(σi,σ−i)>ui(si,σ−i) for all σ−i∈Σ−i.

In each step, we consider eliminate all dominated strategies.

Social Welfare and Pareto Optimality

Def. A strategy profile s that maximizes social welfare is a social optimum.

  • Ingeneral, "social welfare" is hard to define since payoff for different players can't be compared.

Def. (Pareto dominance) A strategy profile s Pareto dominates s0 if ∀i∈I, ui(s)≥ui(s0), and ∃i∈I, ui(s)>ui(s0). Intuitionally, no one's payoff gets worse and someone's gets better.

A strategy profile s is Pareto optimal if it is not Pareto dominated.

  • Prop. There always exists at least one Pareto optimal strategy profile in a finite game, might be multiple. (Otherwise, there would be a cycle by finiteness)
  • Prop. A social optimum strategy profile s is always Pareto optimal.
  • Kaldor-Hicks efficiency: When one’s improvement is larger than others’ lost, potentially reach Pareto improvement by compensation.

Rationalizability

Def. (Belief) A belief µi of player i about the other player’s strategies is a probability measure on σ−i∈Πj≠iΣj . A rational player plays best response to his belief.

Def. (Never-best response) A pure strategy si is a never-best response if for all beliefs σ−i , there exists σi∈Σi such that ui(σi,σ−i)>ui(si,σ−i). A strictly dominated strategy is a never-best response, but the inverse may not true.

Def. (Rationalizable strategies) Ri∞, which contains all strategies that survive iterative elimination of never-best response, is the set of rationalizable strategies.

  • A strictly dominated strategy will not be rationalized.
  • Thus, set of rationalizable strategies represent a further refinement of the strategy beyond iterated strict dominance.
  • What’s left in the rationalizable set is what a rational player might play.

Thm. (Pearce, 1984) Rationalizability and iterated strict dominance coincide in two-player games.

Remark. (1) This doesn't hold for multi-player games (2) Only need to show a never-best pure strategy is always strivtly dominated.

Thm6. (Supporting Hyperplane Theorem) Let C be a nonempty convex subset of Rn and let x0 be a vector in Rn . If x0 is not an interior point of C, there exists a hyperplane that passes through x0 and contains C in one of its closed halfspaces, i.e., there exists a vector a→∈Rn , a→≠0 s.t.

aTx0≥aTx,∀x∈C.

Correlated Equilibrium

Def. (Correlated Equilibrium) A correlated equilibrium of a finite game is a joint probability distribution p over ∆(S) such that

∑s−i∈S−ip(s−i|si)ui(si,s−i)≥∑s−i∈S−ip(s−i|si)ui(si′,s−i),∀si′∈Si.

for every player i and every si with p(si)>0.

Intuition: given a signal si generated from p, and when everyone else is following the signal, then your best choice is to follow the signal.

Prop. Every mixed strategy Nash equilibrium is a correlated equilibrium.

 

Lecture 5 : Existence of Nash Equilibrium

Review: DSE ⊂ PSNE ⊂ MSNE ⊂ CE

Nash's Theorem

Thm1. Every finite game has at least one MSNE.

Thm2. (Brouwer's Fixed Point Theorem) Let C be a bounded convex and closed subset of the Euclidean space. If f:C→C is a continuous function, there exists x∈C s.t. f(x)=x.

Proof

Def. Suppose the strategy profile σ∈Σ is given. For player i and a pure strategy s∈Si, define the gain function of player i as Gi(s,σ)=max{ui(s,σ−i)−ui(σ),0} The gain is the increase of payoff for player i if he switches to pure strategy s.

Define a function f:Σ→Σ as follows: for all σ∈Σ, f(σ)=σ′ , where for all i and si∈Si,

σi′(si)=σi(si)+Gi(si,σ)1+∑si∈SiG(si,σ)

f is continuous, Σ=∏Σi​ is convex, bounded and closed, so we can tell that there exists a a fixed point. σ=f(σ), thus Gi(s,σ)=0,∀i,s∈Si

Fixed Point Theorems

Lemma. (Sperner's Lemma) Consider a triangle T with vertices v1,v2,v3. Let T be a triangulation of T and and V(T) denote its set of vertices. Consider any coloring of V(T) with {0,1,2} such that

  1. vi is colored with i(i∈{0,1,2}).
  2. If v∈V(T) lies on the line joining vertices vi,vj colored in i,j∈{0,1,2}, the color of v is either i or j. Then, there exists at least one trianle in T whose vertices are colored by all three colors.

Remark. (1) There is a stronger version of Sperner’s lemma that further guarantees the total number of tri-chromatic triangles in T to be odd. (2) The results holds for higher dimension case.

proof. Routing

Thm. (Kakutani) Let φ be a correspondence on set S, with x∈S→φφ(x)⊆S. Suppose we have the following conditions:

  • S is a non-empty, compact and convex subset of Euclidean space Rn.
  • φ(x) is non-empty and convex-valued for all x∈S. That is, ϕ(x) is a convex set for all x.
  • φ has a closed graph. That is, {(x,y):y∈ϕ(x)} is a closed set.

Then φ has a fixed point. That is, there exists some x∈S such that x∈φ(x).

Proof via Kakutani's Theorem

Recall the definition of best response BRi(σ−i)={σi:arg⁡maxσi∈Σiui(σi,σ−i)}. Define the correspondence as BR(σ)={σ′|σi′∈BRi(σ−i)},∀i.

  • (Nash 1950) The idea is to apply Kakutani’s fixed point theorem to the best-response correspondence BR(σ):Σφ→Σ.
  • Σ is compact and non-empty. BR(σ) is non-empty and convex-valued, and has a closed graph.
  • Thus a fixed point exists, and the fixed point is a Nash equilibrium.

More Existence Examples

Thm. (D-G-F) For a strategic game G={I,(Si)i∈I,(ui)i∈I}. If

  • I is a finite set; Si is compact and convex;
  • ui(si,s−i) is continuous in s−i ; ui(si,s−i) is continuous and quasi-concave in si ,

then there exists a pure strategy Nash equilibrium.

Def. A mapping T:(M,d)→(M,d) is called a contraction mapping if for some 0≤β<1 and ∀x,y∈X:

(Lipcshitz condition)d(T(x),T(y))≤βd(x,y)

Thm. (Contration Mapping Theorem) Let (X,d) be a non-empty complete metric space, then any contraction f:X→X has a unique fixed point. Thm. If the best response mapping is a contraction on the entire strategy space, then there is a unique NE. Example: Cournot

Lecture 6-7 : Extensive Form Games

Extensive Form Game: proposed to analyze dynamic games

Dynamic Game

In this lecture, we consider complete information (describles the game itself) case, i.e.

  • player set, structure of the game, available actions at each state, the payoff of the outcomes.

Also restrict to perfect recall where players remember all infomation he received during the play.

Game Tree

The extensive form game can be represented by a rooted tree T.

  • Nodes. Each node in T represents a possible state in the game.

    • Terminal nodes (outcome) Z. Each leaf state results in a certain payoff for each player.
    • Decision nodes. Each decision node v in T is associated with one of the players, indicating that it is his turn to play when v is reached.
    • Exogenous events can be treated as decisions of the player of “Nature”, i.e., the “chance nodes”.

  • Edges. The edges from an internal node to its resulting children node represents the an action and the corresponding next state. All edges from a node shows the possible moves of the player.

We exclude loops and multiple roots. Each non-root node has exactly one immediate parent.

Imformation set

Perfect Infomation: during play, each player knows the complete history of previous moves, and hence which state of the game he is currently at. (Imperfect imformation)

Imformation set: An information set h of player i are the inner nodes of the game tree.

  • All information sets h∈H partitions the game tree, i.e., every node is in exactly one information set.

  • For an information set hi of player i:

    • player i makes the move for any state u∈hi, available actions for any u,v∈h are the same.
    • given any u,v∈hi , player i cannot distinguish which state he is currently at.

  • When making decisions, the player knows which information set he's in.

  • Game of perfection information is the special case when all information sets are singletons.

  • Perfect recall rules out the possibility that u is predecessor of v while in the same information set.

Let Hi be the set of player i’s information sets, and Ai=∪hi∈HiA(hi) be the set of all actions for player i

Def. A pure strategy for player i is a map si:Hi→Ai such that si(h)∈A(h) for all h∈Hi .

Turning into Normal Form

Turnning into normal form is like every player plans ahead and chooses a strategy at the beginning.

Def 2. A mixed strategy σi of a player i in an extensive form game is a distribution over pure strategies,

σi∈∆Si=∆(∏h∈HiA(h)).

The behavioral strategy specifies a probability distribution over actions at each hi, and the probabilities at different information sets are independent:

Def 3. (Behavioral strategy) A behavioral strategy bi​ of player i​ is a product distribution on actions Ai​ at each information set h:

bi∈∏h∈Hi∆(A(h)).

Def 4. (Realization Equivalence)

Thm. In a game of perfect call, mixed and behavior strategies are equivalent.

  • Every mixed strategy is equivalent to the unique behavioral strategy it generates.

Subgame Perfection

Def. (Subgame) A subgrame G′ of extensive form game G is a subtree of game tree of G that:

  • begins at a singleton information set, includes all subsequent nodes, and does not cut any information sets.

with perfect information, every subtree is a subgame.

Def. (Subgame Perfect Equilibrium) A (behavioral) strategy profile σ∗ is a subgame perfect equilibrium of G if σ∗|G′ is a Nash equilibrium of every subgame G′ of G.

Backward Induction For finite games

  1. Find terminal subgames
  2. Solve terminal subgames (Nash Equilirium is guaranteed to exist)
  3. Calculate the Nash equilibrium payoffs of the terminal subgames, and replace these subgames with the Nash payoffs.

Thm 3. Any finite extensive form game has a SPE. (Informal proof: beckward induction)

Cor 4. (Zermelo's Thm) Any finite game of perfect information has a pure strategy SPE.

 

Stackelberg Game

Stackelberg game: leader and follower. Leader moves first (commit), and then follower moves.

  • Key: leader predicts and moves, follower responses.

The objective of the follower is to best response the leader: BR(σl)=arg⁡maxσf∈∆fuf(σl,σf). The goal of the leader can be represented as follows: maxσl∈∆lul(σl,σf) s.t. σf∈BR(σl).

  • Any problem in this optimization? BR(σl) may be a set value function.

Def. (Strong Stackelberg Equilibirum) We assume that the follower breaks ties in favor of the leader. This is an optimistic (in terms of the leader) view of the play. (Weak Stackelberg Equilibrium) The follower breaks the tie adversarially.

  • SSE guarantees existence, while WSE doesn't.

Thm. (Leader's Advantege) In a Stackelberg game, the leader achieves weakly more utility in SSE than in any Nash equilibrium.

Example: inspection, Security game

Multi-stage Game with Observed Actions

Multi-stage game with observed actions: The game has K stages;

  • in each stage k, every player knows all the actions that were taken at any previous stage;
  • each player moves at most once within a given stage;
  • In each stage everyone moves “simultaneously”.

It could be too cumbersome (exponentially increasing) to construct game tree to describe multi-stage game. We abuse h to also define "history" in the multi-stage game. (history = information set)

Denote Ai(hk+1) as player i's possible actions in stage k+1 with history hk+1.

Thm 6. In a finite multi-stage game with observed actions, strategy profile σ is subgame perfect if and only if it satisfies the one-shot deviation condition, i.e., there is no player i and no strategy σ^i that agrees with σi except at a single stage t and history ht, and that σ^i is a better response to σ−i than σi at history ht.
